Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>[...]
>
>Of course, whether or not they were used does not detract from the 
>legitimacy of your question.  It is certainly still interesting the 
>rate at which genes should be disabled or reinstated, and it is 
>quite related to the work on pruning that e.g. Colin has been doing 
>with SharpNEAT, or Derek and Philip have been doing with ANJI (these 
>people are all in this group).  Although they use actual deletion 
>operators, it is still related to disabling and the overall question 
>of how much to simplify vs. complexify.  I'm not sure if you've seen 
>any of their work in this area?
>  
>
Yeh SharpNEAT no longer has a disable flag on the connection genes, they 
are either present and therefore expressed in the network, or they are 
deleted for good. Of course a gene that is deleted from one genome may 
still exist elsewhere in the population, so just because it has been 
deleted from a specific genome doesn't mean it can't make a comeback in 
that genome's descedant line at some point in the future.

As I recall my main reason for removal of the disable bit was that I 
felt it was redundant following the implementation of the 'delete gene' 
mutation. I also felt that keeping a lot of diabled genes around would 
effect performance of the  NEAT algorithm by causing genome 'bloat' - 
how many diabled genes do you want to keep? How many is too many? etc.

There is bit more backround on the use of deletion mutations in my write 
up of my phased complexification/simplification search experiments here:

http://sharpneat.sourceforge.net/phasedsearch.html

Regards,

Colin
